{{Infobox museum | name = Byzantine Fresco Chapel | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_upright = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = ByzantineFrescoChapelMuseum.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = The exterior of the Byzantine Fresco Chapel in Houston | map_type = USA Texas | map_relief = | map_size = | map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|29.7364|-95.3953|type:landmark_region:US-TX|display=inline}} | former_name = | established = {{Start date|1997|09}}, reopened {{Start date|2015}} | dissolved = {{End date|2011}} | location = [[Houston]], Texas, U.S. | type = | accreditation = | key_holdings = | collections = | collection_size = | visitors = | founder = | director = | president = | ceo = | chairperson = | curator = | architect = | historian = | owner = | publictransit = | car_park = | parking = | network = | website = {{URL|http://www.byzantinefrescochapel.org/}} | embedded = }} The '''Byzantine Fresco Chapel''' is a part of the [[Menil Collection]] in [[Houston, Texas]], near the [[University of St. Thomas (Texas)|University of St. Thomas]]. From February 1997 to February 2012, it displayed the only intact [[Byzantine]] [[frescoes]] of this size and importance in the entire western hemisphere. The Byzantine frescoes had been taken from the church of [[Church of Saint Evphemianos, Lysi|St. Evphemianos]] in [[Lysi]], [[Cyprus]] in the 1980s. In September 2011, the collection announced that the frescos would be permanently returned to Cyprus in February 2012, following the conclusion of a long-term loan agreement with the [[Church of Cyprus|Greek Orthodox Church of Cyprus]].<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424053111903703604576587072924927678 "From Texas at Age 700"]. ''Wall Street Journal'', September 24, 2011. Retrieved January 8, 2017. {{paywall}}</ref> The frescoes had been presented at the museum by agreement with the Church of Cyprus, their owners, but the church decided not to extend the loan further. They will not return to their original home as Lysi is now in [[Northern Cyprus]], but will be displayed at the Byzantine Museum in [[Nicosia]].<ref>[http://houston.culturemap.com/newsdetail/09-23-11-20-43-menil-returning-byzantine-frescoes-to-cypress/ "See them while you can: Menil returning Byzantine frescoes to Cyprus in February 2012"]. ''Houston Culturemap'', September 23, 2011. Retrieved September 26, 2011</ref> On March 4, 2012, the Byzantine Fresco Chapel closed, but re-opened in 2015 for the first in a series of site-specific projects.
==History== The chapel was opened in February 1997, and displayed masterworks from the 13th century—a dome with [[Christ Pantocrator]] and an [[apse]] depicting the [[Virgin Mary]] the [[Panayia]]. The frescoes had been stolen from a chapel near Lysi in the [[Turkish invasion of Cyprus|Turkish-occupied]] section of [[Cyprus]] in the 1980s, cut into 38 pieces, and shipped to Germany by thieves to sell them in the arts black-market.<ref name="Slessor, Christine 1998">Slessor, Christine. "Out of this world – Chapel Museum, Houston, Texas – Glass and Transparency." ''The Architectural Review''. May, 1998.</ref> The 38 fresco fragments were bought from the thieves by the Houston-based Menil Foundation on behalf of the Church of Cyprus, the rightful owner of the frescoes. The Menil Foundation then funded a careful restoration of the paintings.<ref name="Menil Collection website">[https://www.menil.org/exhibitions/226-byzantine-fresco-chapel Byzantine Fresco Chapel]. ''www.menil.org''.</ref> These intact frescoes were unique in the western hemisphere.<ref name="Menil Collection website" />
==The original collection== [[File:Lysi-dome.jpg|thumb|left|Dome from church in Lysi, Cyprus depicting Christ the Pantokrator]] The major part of the collection consisted of the frescoes of the dome and apse. According to the guide to the museum, "the Lysi dome represents Christ Pantokrator, 'All sovereign'. It defines a space with no beginning and no end."<ref name="ReferenceA">Guide to the Byzantine Fresco Chapel Museum.</ref> The depiction of Christ gazing directly forward "has driven time out of space. His gaze is transworldly: not looking but all-seeing."<ref name="ReferenceA" /> By not depicting the Lord below the bust, he is "universal and ubiquitous."<ref name="ReferenceA" /> Surrounding the figure of Christ is a double row of angels moving towards the throne prepared by God the Father for the [[Second Coming of Christ]]. The throne is guarded by the [[Archangel Michael]] and [[Archangel Gabriel]] and two [[seraphim]]. The [[Virgin Mary]] leads one line of angels to the throne, while [[John the Baptist]] leads the other.
In the apse, the Virgin was depicted as flanked by the two archangels with a medallion on her breast of the infant Christ, symbolizing the [[Incarnation]] of Christ.<ref name="ReferenceA" />
==Later exhibits== ''The Infinity Machine''. This rotating work by [[Janet Cardiff]] & [[George Bures Miller]] incorporates an array of antique mirrors suspended from above, accompanied by sonic elements made from [[NASA]] recordings of solar winds interacting with planetary ionospheres.<ref>Glentzer, Molly. [http://www.houstonchronicle.com/entertainment/arts-theater/article/Menil-s-new-Inifinity-exhibit-is-a-great-place-6051563.php "Menil's new Infinity exhibit is a surreal space experience."] ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'', January 30, 2015. Retrieved 2 May 2015</ref><ref>[http://houston.culturemap.com/news/arts/02-06-15-menil-byzantine-chapel-is-reborn-as-iinfinity-machinei-with-dazzling-mirrors-voices-from-the-planets/#slide=0 "Menil Byzantine Chapel is reborn as Infinity Machine with dazzling mirrors & voices from the planets"]. ''http://houston.culturemap.com'', February 6, 2015. Retrieved January 8, 2017.</ref>
==Architecture== [[File:ByzantineChapelMuseum.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Church within a Museum; the glass and wood chapel that housed the only intact Byzantine frescoes in the Western hemisphere]] The {{convert|4000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} $4 million building was designed by architect [[François de Menil]]. The interior combines rough stone, opaque glass, and rich woods, to create a space that is both art museum and spiritual space.<ref>[http://www.houstonmuseumdistrict.org/default/museumpages/museumpage.asp?MID=15 "Byzantine Fresco Chapel"]. ''Houston Museum District''. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208080959/http://www.houstonmuseumdistrict.org/default/museumpages/museumpage.asp?MID=15 |date=February 8, 2012}}. Retrieved January 8, 2017.</ref> The suspended-glass "walls" are not replicas of the chapel that the frescoes were removed from, but created a new context for displaying the icons. In order not to simply replicate the original chapel, de Menil designed "a mediating external building with an embedded steel structure – a 'reliquary box' – which forms a neutral enclosure for a freestanding chapel," according to Christine Slessor in ''The Architectural Review''.<ref name="Slessor, Christine 1998" />
{{quote|"The Byzantine Chapel Museum is a religious building whose purpose is to restore spiritual significance and function to two thirteenth-century Byzantine Frescoes, a dome and an apse, rescued and restored by the owner ... The materiality of the original chapel is shattered and made ephemeral through the fragmented, freestanding sandblasted laminated glass structure which is an abstracted evocation of the original chapel. The infinite is evoked through the play of darkness and light." François de Menil, May 1997<ref>[http://www.dupont.com/safetyglass/lgn/stories/0802.html "Byzantine Fresco Chapel Museum uses sandblasted laminated glass to restore spiritual significance"]. ''Laminated Glass News'', E.I. Dupont de Nemours Company. August 2002.</ref>}}
The Byzantine chapel is oriented to face the cardinal directions – the facades face directly north, south, east and west. The enclosed space measures approximately {{convert|116000|cuft|m3}}. There are no windows on the surface area of the building, except for a skylight of {{convert|1012|sqft|m2}} of clear, double glazed glass, which permits natural light to pervade the interior.<ref>Allan V. Co. [http://www.owlnet.rice.edu/~arch316/byz.pdf Byzantine Fresco Chapel - climatology]. ''[[Rice University]]'', 2002. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040919162203/http://www.owlnet.rice.edu/~arch316/byz.pdf|date=September 19, 2004}} Retrieved January 8, 2017.</ref> A rough limestone wall on the outside of the building evoked the rough construction of the original chapel in Cyprus.<ref name="Slessor, Christine 1998" />

{{refimprove|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox religion |name = Church of Euthanasia |image = [[File:CoE Symbol.gif|180px]] |imagewidth = |caption = The official symbol of the Church of Euthanasia is a representation of a Greek temple with four pillars |abbreviation = CoE |founder = [[Chris Korda]], Robert Kimberk |founded_date = 1992 |founded_place = Registered in the state of [[:pt:Delaware|Delaware]] |headquarters = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]. [[United States]] |website = {{URL|http://churchofeuthanasia.org}} |footnotes = }}
The '''Church of Euthanasia''' (also known as CoE) is a religious organization founded by Reverend [[Chris Korda]] and Pastor Kim (Robert Kimberk) in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], [[United States]] in 1992.<ref>Potts, Grant. (2005) "Church of Euthanasia". In ''[[The Encyclopedia of Religion and Nature]]'', ed. by Bron Taylor, pp. 384–85. London & New York: Continuum International</ref>
As stated in the Church's website, it is "a non-profit educational foundation devoted to restoring balance between Humans and the remaining species on Earth".<ref name="Church of Euthanasia FAQ">[http://churchofeuthanasia.org/coefaq.html Church of Euthanasia FAQ.]</ref> Members of this organization affirm this can only turn into a reality by a massive voluntary population reduction, which will depend on a leap in human consciousness to species-awareness.<ref>Harrison, Ann. (1995) [[The Phoenix (newspaper)|The Boston Phoenix]], [http://www.churchofeuthanasia.org/press/phoenix2.html Virtually childless.]</ref> According to Rev. [[Chris Korda]] it is likely that this Church is the world's only anti-human religion.<ref>Wright, Chris. (2001) [[The Phoenix (newspaper)|The Boston Phoenix]], [http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/news_features/this_just_in/documents/02063812.htm The Pornography of Terror.]</ref>
Its most popular slogan is "Save the Planet, Kill Yourself"<ref>Grad, David. (1996) [[New York Press]], [http://www.churchofeuthanasia.org/press/david_grad.html Eat Me - Rev. Chris Korda Dines For Our Sins.]</ref> and its founding ideology is set in one commandment "Thou Shalt not Procreate",<ref>Blount, Dave. (2015) [http://rightwingnews.com Right Wing News ], [http://rightwingnews.com/abortion/satanists-pro-life-laws-violate-our-religious-beliefs/ Satanists: Pro-Life Laws Violate Our Religious Beliefs.]</ref> and four main pillars: suicide, abortion, cannibalism (of the already dead) and sodomy ("any sexual act not intended for procreation").<ref name="Church of Euthanasia FAQ">[http://churchofeuthanasia.org/coefaq.html Church of Euthanasia FAQ.]</ref> The Church stresses population reduction by voluntary means only.<ref>Dery, Mark. (1999) Getting It, [http://www.churchofeuthanasia.org/press/dery.html Mark Dery Interviews Chris Korda.]</ref>
The Church promotes its environmental views mainly via their [http://churchofeuthanasia.org/ website] and the web. They also utilize [http://churchofeuthanasia.org/e-sermons/e-sermons.html sermons], art performances, public demonstrations, [[culture jamming]], music, [[publicity stunts]] and direct action to highlight [[human overpopulation|Earth's unsustainable population]]. They consider their methodology similar to those of the [[Dada|Dadaist movement]],<ref>Broder, Von; M, Henryk. (1996) [[Der Spiegel]], [http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-9123239.html Macht Liebe, nicht Babies], [http://www.churchofeuthanasia.org/press/derspieg.html English translation.]</ref> finding the modern world so absurd that the means needed to reach their message to the public must be absurd themselves.
The Church of Euthanasia is also notorious for its conflicts with [[Anti-abortion movements|pro-life]] [[Christian]] activists.<ref>Broder, Von; M, Henryk. (1996) [[Der Spiegel]], [http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-9123239.html Macht Liebe, nicht Babies], [http://www.churchofeuthanasia.org/press/derspieg.html English translation].</ref>
[[Slogan]]s employed by the group include "Save the Planet, Kill Yourself", "Six Billion Humans Can't Be Wrong", and "Eat a Queer Fetus for Jesus".<ref>Prongo, Jark. (2013) [http://vanishingpoint.es/ Vanishing Point], [http://vanishingpoint.es/especiales/chris-korda-y-la-iglesia-de-la-eutanasia-save-the-planet-kill-yourself Chris Korda y la Iglesia de la Eutanasia: save the planet, kill yourself.]</ref>
== History ==
The Church gained early attention in 1995 because of its affiliation with [[paranoia.com]] which hosted many sites that were controversial or skirted illegality. Members later appeared on an episode of ''[[The Jerry Springer Show]]'' titled "I Want to Join a Suicide Cult".<ref>[http://www.oocities.org/entertalkmentsite/jerryspringer.html EnterTalkMent Archives, broadcast Aug 11, 1997.]</ref>
Following the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001 attacks]], the Church posted to its website a four-minute music video titled ''[http://www.churchofeuthanasia.org/catalog/video.html I Like to Watch],'' combining hardcore [[pornography|pornographic]] video with footage of the [[World Trade Center (1973-2001)|World Trade Center]] collapse. The montage featured an electronic soundtrack recorded by Korda and the lyrics, [http://www.lyricsfreak.com/c/chris+korda/save+the+planet+kill+yourself_21009925.html "People dive into the street/ While I play with my meat."] It also showed a man masturbating and then cleaning himself with an American flag. Korda described the project as reflecting his "contempt for and frustration with the profound ugliness of the modern industrial world."<ref>Wright, Chris. (2001) [[The Phoenix (newspaper)|The Boston Phoenix]], The [http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/news_features/this_just_in/documents/02063812.htm Pornography of Terror.]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.spaink.net/2002/11/12/kip-aan-het-kruis/|title = Chicken on the Cross "Kip aan het kruis"|date = November 12, 2002|accessdate = September 21, 2015|website = spaink.com|publisher = Karin Spaink|last = Spaink|first = Karin}}</ref>
The Church's website previously had instructions on "how to kill yourself" by [[asphyxia]]tion using [[helium]]. These pages were removed in 2003 after a 52-year-old woman used them to commit suicide in [[St. Louis County, Missouri]], resulting in legal threats against the church.<ref>Frankel, Todd C. (2003) [[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]], [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=Now%20even%20committing%20suicide%20has%20gone%20online&p_field_date-0=YMD_date&p_params_date-0=date:B,E&p_text_date-0=2000%20-%202008|2011%20-%202014|1988%20-%202000|2000&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=%28%22Now%20even%20committing%20suicide%20has%20gone%20online%22%29&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no Now even committing suicide has gone online].</ref>

US.{{cite web| url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1277559/clayton-homes-i-house-combines-energy-efficiency-and-modular-affordability| title=Clayton Homes' i-house Combines Energy Efficiency and Modular Affordability| author=Ariel Schwartz| date=4 May 2009| publisher=Fast Company| access-date=3 June 2016}} Clayton Homes is owned by [[Warren Buffett]]'s [[Berkshire Hathaway]].{{cite web| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/07/31/business/buffett-wins-battle-to-buy-clayton-homes.html| title=Buffett Wins Battle to Buy Clayton Homes| author=Andrew Ross Sorkin| date=31 July 2003| publisher=The New York Times| access-date=3 June 2016}} Clayton's corporate headquarters are in [[Maryville, Tennessee]].{{cite web| url=https://www.forbes.com/companies/clayton-homes/| title=#292 Clayton Homes| publisher=Forbes| access-date=3 June 2016}} Its subsidiaries include Vanderbilt Mortgage, 21st Mortgage, the nation's largest manufactured home lender,{{cite web| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/dedrick-muhammad/call-for-federal-investig_b_9049580.html| title=Call for Federal Investigation Into Report of Racially Discriminatory Predatory Lending| date=22 January 2016| author=Dedrick Muhammad| publisher=Huffington Post| access-date=3 June 2016}} and insurance company HomeFirst Agency.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/19/realestate/financing-manufactured-homes.html|title=Financing Manufactured Homes|last=Prevost|first=Lisa|date=2014-10-16|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-07-11|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} ==History== Clayton Homes was founded in 1956{{cite web| url=http://www.knoxnews.com/business/clayton-homes-buys-alabama-manufactured-housing-company-30370334-a344-01f5-e053-0100007f4ecc-375295821.html| title=Clayton Homes buys Alabama manufactured-housing company| author=Chambers Williams| date=April 11, 2016| publisher=Knoxville News Sentinel| access-date=June 7, 2016}} by [[Jim Clayton (Clayton Homes)|Jim Clayton]]. In 1974, Clayton Homes established its own mortgage company, and added a manufacturing division in 1975. The company went [[public company|public]] in 1983, trading on the [[New York Stock Exchange]].{{cite web| url=http://www.inc.com/magazine/19830901/2878.html| title=Small Company Initial Public Offerings: June 1983| publisher=Inc.| access-date=June 7, 2016}}{{cite journal| journal=Kentucky New Era| date=February 15, 1991| title=Trailer park 'king' makes big business after humble beginnings in Tennessee| author=Duncan Mansfield| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=266&dat=19910215&id=DPQrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QmoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1283,4190385&hl=en}} Each year from 1989 through 1992, Clayton Homes was named on the [[Forbes]] list of the best small companies in America.{{cite web| url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/12/24/ocwen-would-do-well-to-follow-the-lessons-of-berkshires-clayton-homes/?_r=1| title=Ocwen Would Do Well to Follow the Lessons of Berkshire's Clayton Homes| author=Lawrence A. Cunningham| date=December 24, 2014| publisher=The New York Times| access-date=June 7, 2016}} [[Kevin Clayton]], Jim Clayton's son, took over the company in 1999. In 2002, Clayton earned a revenue of $1.2 billion. It was acquired by Berkshire Hathaway Inc. in 2003 for $1.7 billion.{{cite web| url=http://www.fastcompany.com/48214/ballad-clayton-homes| title=The Ballad of Clayton Homes| author=Jennifer Reingold| date=January 1, 2004| publisher=Fast Company| access-date=June 7, 2016}}{{cite web| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/07/31/business/buffett-wins-battle-to-buy-clayton-homes.html| title=Buffett Wins Battle to Buy Clayton Homes| author=Andrew Ross Sorkin| date=July 31, 2003| publisher=The New York Times| access-date=June 7, 2016}}{{cite web| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB104925717315163800#:WXQd8YV2jONuNA| title=Berkshire Hataway Agrees To Acquire Clayton Homes| date=April 2, 2003| publisher=Wall Street Journal| access-date=June 7, 2016}} Cerberus Capital Management also expressed interest in bidding for the company.{{cite web| url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/industries/manufacturing/2003-07-11-clayton_x.htm| title=Belated suitor woos Clayton Homes| date=July 11, 2003| publisher=USA Today| access-date=September 4, 2016}}{{cite web| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/07/31/business/buffett-wins-battle-to-buy-clayton-homes.html| title=Buffett Wins Battle to Buy Clayton Homes| author=Andrew Ross Sorkin| date=July 31, 2003| publisher=The New York Times| access-date=September 4, 2016}} The certificate of merger was filed in Delaware, and Clayton stock was removed from the [[New York Stock Exchange]].{{cite web| url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-119690083.html| title=Clayton Homes Shareholder Alleges Executive Fraud in Berkshire Hathaway Sale| date=August 27, 2003| author=Amy Nolan| publisher=The Knoxville News Sentinel| access-date=September 4, 2016}}{{cite web| url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-106445429.html| title=Clayton Homes Declares Merger with Berkshire Hathaway, Stops Trading Stock| author=Amy Nolen| date=August 8, 2003| publisher=Knight Ridder Tribune| access-date=September 4, 2016}} In 2007, Clayton Homes' revenue was $3.66 billion.{{cite web| url=http://www.knoxnews.com/business/buffett-gives-clayton-homes-a-high-five-ep-411958871-359952491.html| title=Buffett gives Clayton Homes a high five| author=Amy Nolan| date=March 17, 2008| publisher=Orlando News Setinel| access-date=September 4, 2016}} Clayton Homes sold its land-lease communities business to Denver-based Yes Companies LLC in 2008. The deal involved 65 properties in 11 states.{{cite web| url=http://www.knoxnews.com/business/clayton-completes-sale--of-housing-communities-ep-412041115-359977721.html| title=Clayton completes sale of housing communities| author=Michael Silence| date=February 26, 2008| publisher=Knoxville News Sentinel| access-date=June 7, 2016}}{{cite web| url=http://www.builderonline.com/money/clayton-homes-to-focus-on-subdivision-development_o| title=Clayton Homes to Focus on Subdivision Development| author=John Caulfield| date=March 7, 2008| publisher=Builder Online| access-date=June 7, 2016}} The i-house brand was introduced in May 2008 as a [[Environmentally friendly|green]], [[Efficient energy use|energy efficient]] home.[http://www.popularmechanics.com/technology/engineering/architecture/4299495 Clayton's I-House: Prefab Green Homes Get Affordable]. [[Popular Mechanics]]. January 15, 2009. accessed Jan 5, 2013. By 2009, Clayton Homes had sold over 1.5 million homes.{{cite web| url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/greenhouse/post/2009/12/clayton-homes-offers-low-cost-green-home/1#.VypMFxUrJTZ| title=Clayton Homes joins prefab green building boom with $45,000 eHome| author=Wendy Koch| date=December 9, 2009| publisher=USA Today| access-date=June 7, 2016}} In 2009, Clayton launched the eHome as a more affordable version of the i-house.{{cite web| url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/greenhouse/post/2009/12/clayton-homes-offers-low-cost-green-home/1#.V5jWz5MrIch| title=Clayton Homes joins prefab green building boom with $45,000 eHome| author=Wendy Koch| date=December 9, 2009| publisher=USA Today| access-date=September 4, 2016}} In 2015, Clayton worked with Oak Ridge National Library and architectural firm [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] to produce a [[Construction 3D printing|3D printed house]] and car which share a single energy unit.{{cite web| url=https://3dprint.com/89393/ornl-clayton-homes-3d-print/| title=ORNL & Clayton Homes are 3D printing a home & car that share energy with one another| author=Brian Krassenstein| date=August 2015| publisher=3D Print| access-date=June 7, 2016}}{{cite web| url=http://www.3ders.org/articles/20150923-ornl-unveils-integrated-3d-printed-house-and-car-that-produce-and-share-clean-energy.html| title=ORNL unveils integrated 3D printed house and car that produce and share clean energy| date=September 23, 2015| publisher=3Ders| access-date=June 7, 2016}} Clayton Homes expanded into the traditional home building market with the acquisition of Georgia-based homebuilder Chafin Communities in 2015,{{Cite web| url=http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/news/2015/11/02/buffett-owned-company-buys-georgia-homebuilder-for.html| title=Buffett-owned company buys Georgia homebuilder for $50 million| author=Phil W. Hudson| date=November 2, 2015| publisher=Atlanta Business Chronicle| access-date=June 7, 2016}} and Tennessee-based Goodall Homes in 2016.{{Cite web| url=http://www.builderonline.com/builder-100/strategy/home-building-investment-buffett-style_o| title=Home Building Investment, Buffett-Style| author=John McManus| date=May 2, 2016| publisher=Builder Online| access-date=June 7, 2016}}{{cite web| url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/money/homes/2016/04/29/warren-buffetts-company-buys-builder-goodall-homes/83673456/| title=Warren Buffett's company buys Gallatin's Goodall Homes| author=Getahn Ward| date=April 29, 2016| publisher=The Tennessean| access-date=June 7, 2016}} Clayton acquired River Birch Homes, based in Hackleburg, Alabama, in April 2016. The following month, Clayton hosted its first Birmingham-based home show. The show had 492 attendees and featured 27 homes from 27 facilities.{{cite web| url=http://www.knoxnews.com/business/clayton-homes-marks-60-years-new-directions-343a1271-236c-433e-e053-0100007fac27-381573981.html| title=Clayton Homes marks 60 years, new directions| author=Ed Marcum| date=June 1, 2016| publisher=Knoxville News Sentinel| access-date=September 4, 2016}} That same month, Clayton announced that it would partner with nonprofit Next Step to build a modular duplex in Waco, Texas on a lot owned by NeighborWorks Waco in order to create affordable housing in the Greater Waco area.{{cite web| url=http://www.wacotrib.com/news/business/clayton-homes-neighborworks-waco-join-forces-for-affordable-housing/article_a598860b-6aa4-5e83-8ee0-40bf222d0b86.html| title=Clayton Homes, NeighborWorks Waco join forces for affordable housing| author=Mike Copeland| date=April 18, 2016| publisher=Waco Tribune| access-date=September 4, 2016}} In 2016, Clayton Homes was recognized as number 292 on Forbes' list of America's Best Employers.{{cite web| url=https://www.forbes.com/companies/clayton-homes/ | title=#292 Clayton Homes| author=Kathryn Dill| publisher=Forbes| access-date=September 4, 2016}} The company introduced a line of [[Tiny house movement|tiny homes]] during fall 2016 with the debut of its "Low Country" prototype in [[North Carolina]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.knoxnews.com/business/clayton-home-building-group-unveils-tiny-home-designer-series-3b61819a-47c6-5e09-e053-0100007f9ad8-391938021.html|title=Clayton home building group unveils tiny home designer series|access-date=2016-09-22}} The designer series received media acclaim from ''[[USA Today]]'', ''[[The Post and Courier]]'', among others.{{Cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/nation-now/2016/09/06/tiny-home-designer-series/89901222/|title=Home building group unveils tiny home designer series|access-date=2016-09-22}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/20160912/160919796/clayton-homes-takes-a-turn-from-manufactured-housing-to-introduce-its-own-line-of-tiny-homes-including-a-model-with-charleston-ties|title=Clayton Homes takes a turn from manufactured housing to introduce its own line of ‘tiny homes,’ including a model with Charleston ties|date=2016-09-12|access-date=2016-09-22}} On July 10, 2017, Clayton Properties Group announced the purchase of home building operator, [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]], Alabama-based Harris Doyle Homes.{{Cite news|url=http://www.builderonline.com/builder-100/strategy/alabama-shakes-clayton-buys-birminghams-harris-doyle-homes_o|title=Alabama Shakes: Clayton Buys Birmingham's Harris Doyle Homes|date=2017-07-10|work=Builder|access-date=2017-07-11|language=en}} With this purchase, Berkshire Hathaway's Clayton unit lands its fifth site-build purchase, showing emerging synergies among Warren Buffett's housing ecosystem of companies. Berkshire Hathaway’s Clayton Homes division, known for its factory-built houses, is expanding into the site-built, $250,000-and-under [[Real estate economics|housing market]], as reported on July 30, 2017. Since October 2015 Clayton has acquired homebuilders in Atlanta; Nashville, Tennessee; Kansas City; Denver; and, earlier this month, Birmingham, Alabama, and is building homes on-site at a rate of 2,500 to 3,000 a year.{{Cite news|url=http://www.omaha.com/money/buffett/warren-watch-berkshire-s-clayton-homes-division-expanding-into-/article_3b2ca330-80ab-5830-9a6a-eab66b92f8ac.html|title=Warren Watch: Berkshire’s Clayton Homes division expanding into $250,000-and-under housing market|last=writer|first=Steve Jordon / World-Herald staff|work=Omaha.com|access-date=2017-07-30|language=en}} == Operations == Clayton Homes produces homes under the brand names of Buccaneer Homes,{{Cite web|url=http://www.buccaneerhomebuilders.net/|title=Buccaneer Homes|website=www.buccaneerhomebuilders.net|access-date=2017-07-11}} Cavalier Homes, Clayton Homes, Crest Homes,{{Cite web|url=http://www.cresthomes.com/|title=Crest Homes {{!}} Manufactured Homes, Modular Homes, Mobile Home|last=Homes|first=Crest|website=www.cresthomes.com|access-date=2017-07-11}} Giles Industries,{{Cite web|url=http://gilesindustries.com/|title=Giles Industries|website=gilesindustries.com|access-date=2017-07-11}} Golden West Homes,{{Cite web|url=http://www.goldenwesthomes.com/|title=Golden West Homes {{!}} Manufactured Homes, Modular Homes, Mobile Home|last=Homes|first=Golden West|website=www.goldenwesthomes.com|access-date=2017-07-11}} Karsten Company,{{Cite web|url=http://www.karstenhomes.com/|title=Karsten Homes {{!}} Manufactured Homes, Modular Homes, Mobile Home|last=Homes|first=Karsten|website=www.karstenhomes.com|access-date=2017-07-11}} Marlette Homes,{{Cite web|url=http://www.marlettehomes.com/|title=Marlette Homes {{!}} Manufactured Homes, Modular Homes, Mobile Home|last=Homes|first=Marlette|website=www.marlettehomes.com|access-date=2017-07-11}} Norris Homes, Schult Homes, and Southern Energy Homes. Clayton Homes also owns retail brands Oakwood Homes,{{Cite web|url=https://oakwoodhomesco.com/|title=New Oakwood Homes - Builder in Colorado and Utah|website=oakwoodhomesco.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-11}} TruValue Homes{{Cite web|url=http://truvaluealexandria.com/|title=Tru Value Homes of Alexandria, AL {{!}} Mobile, Modular & Manufactured Homes|website=truvaluealexandria.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-11}} and Luv Homes.Mike Baker and Daniel Wagner, [http://www.seattletimes.com/business/real-estate/the-mobile-home-trap-how-a-warren-buffett-empire-preys-on-the-poor/ Minorities exploited by Warren Buffett’s mobile-home empire] The Seattle Times / BuzzFeed News, December 26, 2015.{{cite web| url=http://www.claytonhomes.com/clayton-brands.cfm| title=Our Modular and Manufactured Home Brands| publisher=Clayton Homes| access-date=3 June 2016}} In 2016, Clayton acquired G&I Homes,{{Cite web|url=http://gihomes.net/|title=G&I Homes, Your Confidence Builder|website=G&I Homes|language=en|access-date=2017-07-11}} a family-run company based in New York.{{cite web| url=http://www.knoxnews.com/business/clayton-acquires-new-york-home-retailer-2b5918a2-5a7a-23c0-e053-0100007fc018-368197471.html| title=Clayton acquired New York home retailer| author=Ed Marcum| date=February 9, 2016| publisher=Knoxville News Sentinel| access-date=September 4, 2016}} ==Hope for the Warriors== In 2015, Clayton Homes released the Patriot home model and partnered with the Hope for the Warriors veterans assistance group. Clayton gave a check for $33,600 to the organization in January.{{cite web| url=http://www.omaha.com/money/clayton-homes-home-had-a-sold-sign-even-before-the/article_8c51ef14-526b-5125-a20b-415277d38c88.html| title=Clayton Homes home had a 'sold' sign even before the meeting| date=May 1, 2016| author=Steve Jordon| publisher=Omaha.com| access-date=September 4, 2016}}{{cite web| url=http://www.dailyiowegian.com/news/local_news/devore-homes-participates-in-large-contribution-to-nonprofit-military-support/article_33451877-4aef-5a17-9425-034d35ff20e2.html| title=DeVore Homes participates in large contribution to nonprofit military support group| date=February 17, 2016| publisher=Daily Iowegian| access-date=September 4, 2016}} Hope For The Warriors works with veterans from all branches of the military as well as post [[September 11 attacks|9/11]] active duty, [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard,]] and reserve service members.{{cite web| url=http://www.osceolaiowa.com/2016/02/10/devore-homes-participates-in-large-contribution-to-nonprofit-military-support-group/a1rqm8b/| title=DeVore Homes participates in large contribution to nonprofit military support group| date=February 16, 2016| publisher=Osceola Sentinel Tribune| access-date=September 4, 2016}}{{cite web| url=http://www.thenewsstar.com/story/news/2016/02/01/homes-plus-participates-contribution-nonprofit-military-support-group/79645890/| title=Homes Plus participates in contribution to military support group| date=February 1, 2016| publisher=The News Star| access-date=September 4, 2016}} In May 2016, Clayton presented a $100,000 check to the organization.{{cite web| url=http://www.mhmarketingsalesmanagement.com/blogs/daily-business-news/tag/hope-for-the-warriors/| title=Clayton Homes Inaugurates Birmingham Home Show| date=May 12, 2016| author=Matthew Silver| publisher=Daily Business News| access-date=September 4, 2016}} ==Controversy== Clayton Homes was involved in a lawsuit in 2011 with FEMA after providing trailers as part of [[Hurricane Katrina]] relief which were found to contain formaldehyde. Afterwards, one of 12 prefab shelters provided to Haiti through the [[Clinton Foundation]] after the 2010 earthquake was found to have a formaldehyde level of 250 [[parts per billion|ppb]], "a very high level" according to a scientist specializing in indoor pollutants at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.Isabel Macdonald and Isabeau Doucet [http://www.thenation.com/article/shelters-clinton-built/ The Shelters That Clinton Built] The Nation, July 11, 2011. In 2015, a news story claimed that Clayton Homes unfairly targets and exploits minority home buyers.Daniel Wagner, Mike Baker. [http://www.publicintegrity.org/2015/04/03/17024/warren-buffetts-mobile-home-empire-preys-poor Warren Buffett's mobile home empire preys on the poor. Billionaire profits at every step, from building to selling to high cost lending] The Center for Public Integrity. April 3, 2015 Clayton Homes was further criticized for its alleged use of corrupt business practices. The company has denied discriminating against its customers or its workers.{{cite web| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/berkshire-buffett-claytonhomes-idUSL2N1660FS| title=Buffett defends Clayton Homes after critics fault its lending| author=Jonathan Stempel| publisher=Reuters| date=February 27, 2016| access-date=June 7, 2016}}{{cite web| url=http://fortune.com/2016/02/27/buffett-defends-3g-clayton/| title=Buffett Defends 3G and Clayton Homes as Berkshire Profit Grows| date=February 27, 2016| publisher=Fortune| access-date=June 7, 2016}} [[Warren Buffett]], the CEO of [[Berkshire Hathaway]], defended Clayton against predatory lending claims in an interview saying: "We have 300,000 loans on the books and in the last 3 years I've not received one letter of complaint from anybody."{{cite web| url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/05/02/warren-buffett-defends-clayton-homes-against-claims-of-predatory-lending.html| title=Warren Buffett defends Clayton Homes against claims of predatory lending| author=Javier E. David| date=May 2, 2015| publisher=CNBC| access-date=June 7, 2016}}Anupreeta Das [https://www.wsj.com/articles/warren-buffett-defends-clayton-homes-1430584843 Warren Buffett Defends Clayton Homes] WSJ, May 2, 2015. {{subscription}} ==See also== {{Portal|United States|Companies}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.claytonhomes.com}} {{Berkshire Hathaway}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Clayton Homes}} [[Category:Berkshire Hathaway]] [[Category:1966 establishments in Tennessee]] [[Category:Companies established in 1966]] [[Category:Companies formerly listed on the New York Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Manufactured home manufacturers]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies based in Tennessee]] [[Category:2003 mergers and acquisitions]] [[Category:Construction and civil engineering companies of the United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tennessee]] [[Category:Housing in the United States]] [[Category:Maryville, Tennessee]]

{{Infobox person | name = David Frank | image = David Drank.jpg | caption = Frank in 2014 | birth_date ={{birth date and age|1958|9|24|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Nakuru]], [[Kenya]] | education = [[Trinity College, Oxford]] | occupation = CEO Dial Square 86 | nationality = British | spouse = Isabelle Frank | children = Oliver, Missie and Bart | salary = | networth = | credits = | URL = | agent = }}
'''David Frank''' (born 24 September 1958) is the CEO of Dial Square 86 and the chairman of The RightsXchange, which is an online marketplace for TV rights.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our Tenants : Somerset House|url=http://www.somersethouse.org.uk/about/tenants|accessdate=2014-04-24|quote=Dial Square 86 is a company specialising in creating, financing and exploiting audio-visual content for media platforms worldwide. Run by David Frank (former CEO of Zodiak Media Group, one of the largest television production companies with the world with annual sales of c£500m).}}</ref> He is the founder of [[RDF Media]] (which created international TV hits [[Faking It (UK TV series)|Faking it]], [[Wife Swap (UK TV series)|Wife Swap]] and [[The Secret Millionaire]]) and former CEO of [[Zodiak Media|Zodiak Media SA]] (the super-indie whose portfolio of hits include [[The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009 film)|The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo]], [[Totally Spies!]] and [[The Inbetweeners]]).<ref>{{cite news|last=Curtis|first=Chris|title=Frank has digital ambitions|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/people/frank-has-digital-ambitions/5060821.article|work=Broadcast|date=2013-09-26}}</ref> He is also Chairman (and a shareholder) of Mint Digital, a digital product development studio in London and New York,<ref>{{cite news|last=Parker|first=Robin|title=Supernanny's Lee joins Mint|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/supernannys-lee-joins-mint/455633.article|work=Broadcast|date=2008-01-09|quote=RDF chief executive David Frank is Mint's chairman.}}</ref> and [[Objekt Films]], a London-based film and video content creation company.<ref>{{cite web|title=About: Objekt Films |url=http://www.objekt.co.uk/about|accessdate=2015-06-23|quote=David Frank goes back to roots with son to create Objekt Films}}</ref> Frank is a lifelong Arsenal fan.
==Personal life and education== Frank was born in [[Nakuru]], [[Kenya]], the son of Joy (née Sollis) and Peter Frank. He was educated at [[Trinity College, Oxford]], where he graduated with a BA in [[Jurisprudence]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Curtis|first=Chris|title=David Frank, Zodiak Media Group|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/in-depth/the-braodcast-interview/david-frank-zodiak-media-group/5018563.article|work=Broadcast|date=2010-09-22}}</ref> Frank is married to Isabelle (née Tuquet de Beauregard) Frank. They have three children: Oliver (b. 1985), Missie (b. 1987), and [[Objekt Films|Bart]] (b. 1990) and live in London.
==Career== Prior to running one of the world's biggest TV production companies<ref>{{cite news|last=Roxborough|first=Scott|title=Marc-Antoine d’Halluin Replaces David Frank as Zodiak Media CEO|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/marc-antoine-d-halluin-replaces-634556|date=2013-09-23}}</ref> Frank spent five years working in investment banking in London, first with [[Hill Samuel]] and latterly with [[Swiss Bank Corporation]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Curtis|first=Chris|title=David Frank, Zodiak Media Group|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/in-depth/the-braodcast-interview/david-frank-zodiak-media-group/5018563.article|work=Broadcast|date=2010-09-22}}</ref> Following his time in finance he decided to pursue a career in journalism, first in newspapers - [[Euromoney]] - and subsequently working for the [[BBC]] as a television reporter specialising in business and finance.<ref>{{cite news|title=57. David Frank|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/jul/09/mediatop1002007.mondaymediasection54|newspaper=The Guardian|date=2007-07-09}}</ref>
===RDF Media=== After three years at the BBC, he left to set up his own independent production company, RDF Media, in 1993 with £35,000 start-up capital.<ref>{{cite news|title=INDIE FINANCE - Building RDF into a TV money-spinner|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/indie-finance-building-rdf-into-a-tv-money-spinner/1175382.article|work=Broadcast|date=2001-05-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Zodiak gets Frank with RDF acquisition|url=http://www.c21media.net/zodiak-gets-frank-with-rdf-acquisition/?ss=David+Frank|work=C21 Media|date=2010-06-02}}</ref> His brother, Matthew Frank, joined RDF in 1994 to establish the company's distribution arm.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kemp|first=Stuart|title=Zodiak Rights Hires Steve Macallister as CEO|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/zodiak-rights-hires-steve-macallister-669826|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=2014-01-10}}</ref> Originally the company focused on the production of factual programmes but rapidly expanded into other genres such as entertainment, drama and children's, establishing itself as a leading force in TV production in the UK.
Within 10 years RDF was turning over around £32m a year. In 2000 the company established a successful presence in the US.<ref>{{cite news|title=INDIE FINANCE - Building RDF into a TV money-spinner|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/indie-finance-building-rdf-into-a-tv-money-spinner/1175382.article|work=Broadcast|date=2001-05-18}}</ref>
In 2002, Frank turned down the opportunity to become the Chief Executive at [[Channel Five (UK)]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Deans|first=Jason|title=RDF head shortlisted for C5 top job|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/dec/16/independentproductioncompanies.broadcasting|work=The Guardian|date=2002-12-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Frank pulls out of Five chief race|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/frank-pulls-out-of-five-chief-race/1166950.article|newspaper=Broadcast|date=2002-12-19}}</ref>
By 2005, revenues exceeded £40m and the company was floated on the London Stock Exchange (AIM) with a valuation of £49m.<ref>{{cite news|title=57. David Frank|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2007/jul/09/mediatop1002007.mondaymediasection54|newspaper=The Guardian|date=2007-07-09}}</ref>
In 2006, RDF won its third 'Best Independent Production Company' award at the annual Broadcast Awards, adding to wins in 2002 and 2004. It was the first and, as of 2016, the only company to have won the award three times.<ref>http://www.investegate.co.uk/articlePrint.aspx?id=200512011428499951U</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Broadcast Awards 2002|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/broadcast-awards-2002/1136572.article|newspaper=Broadcast|date=2002-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Broadcast Awards winners 2004|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/broadcast-awards-2004-winners/1088438.article|newspaper=Broadcast|date=2004-02-13}}</ref>
====Queengate Affair==== In July 2007, RDF became embroiled in a controversy concerning a documentary series the company was making about the [[Elizabeth II|Queen]].<ref>{{cite news|title=RDF results hit by Crowngate|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/rdf-results-hit-by-crowngate/211250.article|newspaper=Broadcast|date=2007-10-31}}</ref> The incident, which became known as Queengate, centred on manipulation of footage in a promotional tape for the series which was shown to journalists at a [[BBC One]] press event purporting to show the Queen storming out of a photoshoot with [[Annie Liebowitz]]. The affair led to the resignations of RDF Director of Programmes [[Stephen Lambert (media executive)|Stephen Lambert]] and BBC One Controller [[Peter Fincham]].<ref>{{cite news|title=RDF to miss targets as suspension hits home|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/rdf-to-miss-targets-as-suspension-hits-home/212796.article|newspaper=Broadcast|date=2007-10-31}}</ref>
====Management Buy-Out==== The controversy resulted in a sharp fall in the RDF share price on [[Alternative Investment Market|AIM]]. In 2009, with revenues now of approximately £150m and in response to the fall in the share price, Frank led a management buy-out of the company's shares supported by Dutch private equity firm Dasym Investment Strategies (formerly Cyrte Investments).<ref>{{cite news|last=Bulkley|first=Kate|title=RDF steels itself with £2m in cost savings|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/rdf-steels-itself-with2m-in-cost-savings/1994175.article|work=Broadcast|date=2009-02-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Loveday|first=Samantha|title=RDF MBO closes|url=http://www.licensing.biz/news/read/rdf-mbo-closes/035649|work=Licensing|date=2009-02-05}}</ref>
In July 2010, RDF Media was sold to Zodiak Entertainment, for a reported £150m, and Frank was appointed the CEO of the enlarged group, now renamed Zodiak Media.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sweney|first=Mark|title=RDF Media sold to Zodiak Entertainment|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/jun/02/rdf-media-sold-zodiak-entertainment|work=The Guardian|date=2010-06-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Rushton|first=Katherine|title=Zodiak closes RDF deal|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/indies/zodiak-closes-rdf-deal/5014519.article|work=Broadcast|date=2010-06-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Rushton|first=Katherine|title=Zodiak deal transforms RDF|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/indies/zodiak-deal-transforms-RDF/5014586.article|work=Broadcast|date=2010-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Loveday|first=Samantha|title=RDF rebrands as Zodiak Media Group|url=http://www.licensing.biz/news/read/rdf-rebrands-as-zodiak-media-group/032431|work=Licensing|date=2010-09-22}}</ref>
===Zodiak Media=== The acquisition of RDF Media, in 2010, created a £500m "super-indie" global production giant, Zodiak Media.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rushton|first=Katherine|title=Zodiak closes RDF deal|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/indies/zodiak-closes-rdf-deal/5014519.article|work=Broadcast|date=2010-06-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Zodiak gets Frank with RDF acquisition|url=http://www.c21media.net/zodiak-gets-frank-with-rdf-acquisition/?ss=David+Frank|work=C21 Media|date=2010-06-02}}</ref> Zodiak Media is an independent media company that produces entertainment, factual, drama and kids' programming, with 45 companies operating in 17 countries and $800 million in annual revenues.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bulkey|first=Kate|title=Signs of Zodiak's next move|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/comment/kate-bulkley/signs-of-zodiaks-next-move/5038124.article|accessdate=7 December 2012|newspaper=Broadcast|date=2012-02-17}}</ref> It is headquartered in [[Paris]] and with other key offices in [[London]], [[Los Angeles]], [[Milan]], [[Stockholm]] and [[Moscow]]. It is majority-owned by Italian conglomerate [[De Agostini]] and operates across the world.<ref>{{cite web|last=Keslassy|first=Elsa|title=New Zodiak chief overseas expansion|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118049715|publisher=Variety|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref>
Following his appointment as CEO in July 2010, Frank rebranded Zodiak Entertainment as Zodiak Media and organised the group along geographical divisions to replace the acquired group brands ([[Marathon Media Group]], Magnolia, Zodiak Entertainment and RDF Media). He launched a “creativity and innovation unit” at the centre of the group to look for shows and formats with the best chance of becoming international hits. In 2011 Zodiak acquired UK comedy producer [[Bwark Productions]] (makers of hit TV series and movie [[The Inbetweeners]]). Under Frank, the group also made its first scripted series for a US broadcaster ([[Being Human (North American TV series)|Being Human]] for [[SyFy]] Channel). Frank also oversaw a $267m refinancing of the group's debt through a deal with a syndicate of international banks.<ref>{{cite web|last=Keslassy|first=Elsa|title=New Zodiak chief overseas expansion|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118049715|publisher=Variety|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref>
Frank informed majority owner De Agostini several months prior to his departure of his intent to leave Zodiak at the end of 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last=Walsh|first=Barry|title=David Frank leaving Zodiak, successor appointed|url=http://kidscreen.com/2013/09/23/david-frank-leaving-zodiak-successor-appointed/|work=Kidscreen|date=2013-09-23}}</ref>
During his two decades in TV, Frank gained a reputation as an executive who, although driven by business, was capable of creating a very enjoyable working environment.<ref>{{cite news|title=INTERVIEW - Facts and figures|url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/interview-fact-and-figures/1222840.article|work=Broadcast|date=1999-09-08|quote='don't take things too seriously,' Durkin says.}}</ref>
===Dial Square 86 and TRX=== Frank is the CEO of Dial Square 86, which he founded after leaving Zodiak Media. The company launched in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith |first=Oliver |url=http://www.cityam.com/1413172840/veteran-tv-boss-raises-30m-fund-takeovers |title=Veteran TV boss David Frank raises £30m to fund takeovers |publisher=City AM |date=2014-10-13 |accessdate=2014-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=White |first=Peter |url=http://www.broadcastnow.co.uk/news/people/dial-square-86-buys-talent-agency-in-first-deal/5078441.article |title=Dial Square 86 buys talent agency in first deal |publisher=Broadcastnow.co.uk |date=2014-10-09 |accessdate=2014-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Krewen |first=Nick |url=http://realscreen.com/2014/10/09/dial-square-86-names-cfo-acquires-red-hare-digital/ |title=Dial Square 86 names CFO, acquires Red Hare Digital |publisher=Realscreen |date=2014-10-09 |accessdate=2014-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Dams |first=Tim |url=http://www.televisual.com/blog-detail/David-Frank-turns-up-the-Dial_bid-685.html |title=David Frank turns up the Dial. |publisher=Televisual |date=2014-11-18 |accessdate=2014-11-24}}</ref>
In June 2015, Frank announced the creation of The RightsXchange (TRX),<ref>{{cite web|title=The RightsXchange|url=http://www.trx.tv|website=The RightsXchange|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref> an online marketplace for TV rights.<ref>{{cite web|title=David Frank's Dial Square launching virtual market|url=http://tbivision.com/news/2015/06/david-franks-dial-square-launching-virtual-market/446012/|accessdate=2015-06-19|quote=Dial Square 86, the media investment company run by David and Matthew Frank, is launching a digital platform that will allow distributors and buyers to work together within a new ‘virtual market’.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Dial Square 86 preps online content marketplace|url=http://realscreen.com/2015/06/18/dial-square-86-preps-online-content-marketplace/|accessdate=2015-06-19|quote=Dial Square 86, the latest business venture from former Zodiak Media Group executives David and Matthew Frank, is unveiling its RightsXchange (TRX) platform.}}</ref> David Frank remains CEO of Dial Square 86, the parent company of the new venture, and is also chairman of TRX.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our Team|url=http://www.dialsquare86.com/team|website=Dial Square 86|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref>
In August 2016, TRX announced that it had received co-investment from Sky and Channel 4,<ref>{{cite web|title=Sky and Channel 4 make joint investment to sell more British TV abroad|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/08/11/sky-and-channel-4-make-joint-investment-to-sell-more-british-tv/|quote=Sky and Channel 4 have made a joint investment in a new online service that aims to make it easier for television producers to sell their programmes to foreign broadcasters.|accessdate=2016-08-16|publisher=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|publisher=Variety|accessdate=2016-08-16|url=https://variety.com/2016/digital/news/channel-4-sky-tv-rights-trading-platform-trx-1201835692/|title=Channel 4, Sky Invest in TV Rights Trading Platform TRX}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Channel 4 and Sky invest in startup selling British TV content overseas|url=http://www.cityam.com/247395/channel-4-and-sky-invest-startup-selling-british-tv-content|accessdate=2016-08-16|publisher=City A.M}}</ref> marking the first time that the two companies had jointly invested in a start up.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sky and Channel 4 make joint investment to sell more British TV abroad|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/08/11/sky-and-channel-4-make-joint-investment-to-sell-more-british-tv/|quote=TRX is the first joint investment by Sky and Channel 4.|accessdate=2016-08-16|publisher=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sky, Channel 4 Buy Stakes in TV Rights Online Platform|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/sky-channel-4-buy-stakes-918899|accessdate=2016-08-16|quote=The deal marks the first time Sky and Channel 4 have co-invested in a startup.}}</ref>

[[Image:Manuel Chrysoloras - Imagines philologorum.jpg|thumb|right|Manuel Chrysoloras]]
The '''Erotemata''' are the first printed basic [[Greek language|Greek]] [[grammar]] in use in Western Europe, written by [[Manuel Chrysoloras]] who was a pioneer is spreading [[Greek literature]] in [[Western Europe]].
Chrysoloras' ''Erotemata'' were first published almost certainly in 1471 in [[Venice]] by Adam de Ambergau. It can be considered the first Greek book ever printed, since it bears a Greek title-page and the text contains large parts in Greek. It enjoyed immediate and considerable success in Italy, but also among later leading humanists, being studied by [[Thomas Linacre]] at [[Oxford]] and by [[Desiderius Erasmus]] at [[Cambridge]].<ref> CHRYSOLORAS, Manuel. Erotemata (In Greek).<sup>[http://www.ilab.org/db/detail.php?lang=fr&booknr=305378712][http://www.abebooks.fr/servlet/BookDetailsPL?bi=243219486&searchurl=an%3DCHRYSOLORAS%252C%2BManuel%253B][http://www.forumrarebooks.com/Chrysoloras-Manuel-In-greek.html]</sup></ref>

{{no footnotes|date=July 2015}} '''Gardiner's Sign List''' is a list of common [[Egyptian hieroglyph]]s compiled by Sir [[Alan Gardiner]]. It is considered a standard reference in the study of [[Ancient Egypt]]ian hieroglyphs. Gardiner lists only the common forms of Egyptian hieroglyphs, but he includes extensive subcategories, and also both vertical and horizontal forms for many hieroglyphs. He includes size-variation forms to aid with the reading of hieroglyphs in running blocks of text. In contrast, for example, the [[E. A. Wallis Budge|Budge]] Reference has about 1000 hieroglyphs listed in 50 pages, but with no size variations. Gardiner does not cross-index signs; once put on the list, other significant uses may be overlooked. One example of this is '''G16''', [[nbtỉ]], the ideogram for ''The Two Ladies'', goddesses [[Wadjet]] as the cobra and [[Nekhbet]] as the white vulture. These are the protective and patron goddesses of the separate Egyptian kingdoms that joined into Ancient Egypt, who were both then displayed on the [[uraeus]] of Wadjet when the unification occurred and afterward considered jointly to be the protectors of Egypt and the pharaohs. This ideogram is listed only on the '''bird list''' as G16, and overlooked on the deity list and the reptile list. Other subcategories included by Gardiner are abbreviations and personalized forms, and also a complete subset, used on [[papyrus]], specifically for the [[Book of the Dead]]. ==Categories== === A. ''Hieroglyphics: The Writings of Ancient Egypt'', '''Sun with Rays''', p. 152. Determinative for e.g. ''pḥḏ'' "to shine, illumine" and ''wbn'' "rise"; from this latter case, it can also take the phonetic value of ''wbn'' when standing on its own, e.g. in ''wbn'' "wound". Alternatively, it is either a determiner or ideogram for ''ḥnmmt'', the name of the "sun folk" of [[Heliopolis (ancient Egypt)|Heliopolis]] (Gardiner p. 486).
A depiction with four rays is found on an ivory wand of c. 2100 BC: The "Sun with rays" hieroglyph is shown once, placed upon the head of a ram. It has a central dot, like the [[sun (hieroglyph)|"Sun" hieroglyph]] (N5), with four elongated, undulating vertical rays.Fleming; Lothian; (and Fletcher), 1997. [[File:GPIA-Logo.jpg|thumb|Logo GPIA]] [[File:DEI J 2007.jpg|thumb|The institute in Jerusalem in 2007]] [[File:DEI J 2007 Garten.jpg|thumb|The entrance of the institute in Jerusalem in 2007]] [[File:Garten.jpg|thumb|The garden of the institute in Jerusalem in 2007]] [[File:Theodolit.jpg|thumb|The theodolite used by [[Gottlieb Schumacher]] in the museum of the institute]] [[File:Tall Ziraa 2008 von Westen.jpg|thumb|Tall Zira'a in spring 2008]] The '''German Protestant Institute of Archaeology (GPIA), Research Unit of the German Archaeological Institute''', founded in 1900 is one of the most important biblical archaeological institutes in the Near East. Its [[German language|German]] name is ''Deutsches Evangelisches Institut für Altertumswissenschaft des Heiligen Landes''. == Institutes == The German Protestant Institute of Archaeology, Research Unit of the German Archaeological Institute, operates in two locations – [[Jerusalem]] and [[Amman]]. Its high reputation as cultural institution, help desk, and meeting place for European scholars makes it a sought-after partner for cooperation between German and international organizations and projects. The GPIA is a foundation administered by the [[German Protestant Church]]. At the same time, it serves as a research unit of the [[German Archaeological Institute]] (DAI). They cooperate in several archaeological projects. * Institute [[Jerusalem]], Director-General: Professor Dr. Dr. Dr. h.c. [[Dieter Vieweger]]
Address: Auguste-Victoria-Compound, P.O.Box 18 463, Jerusalem 91184
- Archaeological library, archaeological museum * Institute [[Amman]], Director: Dr. Jutta Häser
Address: P.O.Box 183, Amman 11118, Jordan
- Archaeological library, archaeological collection == Aims == The mission of the institute was clearly stated in its founding charter: the exploration of the Holy Land and its diverse past, cultures and religions. The knowledge acquired was meant to be available to, and discussed by, both experts and the general public. In light of this founding mission, the institute undertakes research on the history and culture of the region. To this end, the institute conducts its own excavations and supports other German research projects. The institute is also committed to disseminating the results of research, especially in the areas of archaeology, cultural studies, theology and the Church. For this purpose, the institute maintains a research library, issues its own archaeological journal and organises meetings, lecture series and exhibitions. Especially important is the Course Programme for theologians, which was founded over 100 years ago by the first director, [[Gustaf Dalman]]. The institute also tries to make archaeological knowledge available to the public by offering guided tours of Jerusalem and the surrounding area. The GPIA fosters close relations with the cultural institutions in the host countries and supports scientific research without any political or religious borders on both sides of the river Jordan. == Archaeological projects == === Tall Zira'a and the Gadara Region Project (Jordan) === Together with the [[Biblical Archaeological Institute]] in [[Wuppertal]], the GPIA conducts the [[Gadara Region Project]] (2001–2020) in the Wadi al-'Arab, south of Umm Qais. The central archaeological site of the Wadi al-'Arab is the [[Tall Zira'a]]. There is hardly an area of Palestine where its history can be studied in such a concentrated manner as in the Wadi al-'Arab. This deep valley, which lies roughly five kilometres south-west of the ancient [[Decapolis]] city of Gadara (today [[Umm Qais]]), is, in many ways, an archaeological bonanza due to the variety in what it has to offer. A number of springs, fertile soils and a moderate climate all provide for excellent living conditions, and the most imposing hill in the valley, Tall Zira'a, possesses its own artesian spring and the very best potential for settlement. In addition, an important trade route ran through the wadi which once linked Egypt with Mesopotamia. The economic success and industriousness of the wadi's inhabitants have left plenty of traces over the millennia. Over one hundred sites mark out the distinguished history of human settlement in the region from the advent of sedentism to the Islamic period. Settlements, canals, water mills, cisterns, oil presses, wine presses, watch towers, graves and, above all, Tall Zira'a with its over 5000 years of settlement activity. === The archaeological park below the Church of the Redeemer (Jerusalem) === The archaeological park opened in November 2012 "The Times", located below the nave of the Church of the Redeemer was co-developed by German Protestant Institute (GPIA) and offers the possibility to commit more than 2000 years of history of the city of Jerusalem by walking through it. The archaeological excavations, conducted by [[Conrad Schick]] 1893 und Ute Wagner-Lux (the former director of GPIA) respectively Karl Vriezen 1970–1974, have been prepared by the German Protestant Institute in the Holy Land in 2009–2012 to present visitors the different stages of development and building of Jerusalem. === Former projects === * Ute Wagner-Lux – [[Madaba]] / [[Jerusalem]] / [[Gadara]], * August Strobel – Kallirrhoë (En ez-Zara), * Gunnar Lehmann; Martin Peilstöcker – Plain of [[Akko]], * Volkmar Fritz – Tell el-Oreme, * Susanne Kerner – [[Gadara Aqueduct|Gadara Tunnel System]] * Thomas Weber – Gadara * Hans-Dieter Bienert; Dieter Vieweger – Esh-Shallaf near Irbid, * Hans-Dieter Bienert; Dieter Vieweger; Roland Lamprichs – Baja near [[Petra]], * Roland Lamprichs – Tall Johfieh, * Michael Heinzelmann – [[Hippos]]. ==History== The GPIA was founded on June 19, 1900, by the Deutsche Evangelische Kirchenkonferenz in Eisenach in order to "maintain, further and regulate the relations between the holy places of biblical history, on the one hand, and between the scientific inquiry and the interests of the Christian faith of the Protestant Church, on the other, in the fields of biblical and ecclesiastical archaeology." Gustaf Dalman – then Professor of Old Testament and Judaic Studies at the [[University of Leipzig]] – was appointed first director and built up the Jerusalem institute. The changed situation after the [[Six-Day War]] in June 1967 necessitated the establishment of the Amman institute. In 1982, the institute in Jerusalem moved to new buildings at the Auguste-Victoria-Compound on the [[Mount of Olives]]. ==External links== * [http://www.deiahl.de/ Institute Homepage] * [https://www.facebook.com/GPIA2 Facebook] * [http://www.tallziraa.de/index.php?lan=1 Tall Zira'a and Gadara Region Project] * [http://www.das-geheimnis-des-tells.de/ Page of the children's book ''The Mystery of the Tall''] {{coord|31|47|10.3|N|35|15|02|E|type:landmark_region:IL-JM|display=inline,title}} [[Category:Archaeology of Jordan]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Jerusalem]] [[Category:Near East]] [[Category:Archaeology of the Near East]] [[Category:Research institutes in Jordan]] [[Category:Research institutes in Israel]] [[Category:Archaeological research institutes]]
